cards.front: What are Newton's laws of motion?
cards.back:
1. An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
2. The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT one of Newton's laws of motion?
options: An apple falls towards the Earth due to its weight (first law)
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction (third law)
A body will remain at rest unless acted upon by a force (second law)
The mass of an object does not affect its acceleration if it is subjected to the same force (inconsistent with Newton's second law)
questions.rationale: The statement 'The mass of an object does not affect its acceleration if it is subjected to the same force (inconsistent with Newton's second law)' is incorrect because it contradicts the principle that an object's acceleration depends on both its mass and the applied force.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: Newton's first law, also known as the law of inertia, states that an object at rest will remain at rest and an object in motion will stay in motion unless acted upon by a net external force. Newton's second law, or F = ma, relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting upon it and its mass, while Newton's third law states that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.
